channel.title: Computer screen
channel.description:
I recently got a flat screen tv to replace my computer monitor but I can't get my screen to go out of the very small and quite annoying resolution of 1024 x 768, even though it is a rather large screen, it just goes black and reverts when I try to do anything. Any tips?
(Image attached is of all the available resolutions the screen shows.)

item.title: Computer screen
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Andrew Ferguson, post:23, topic:431163”][quote author=Fat Cookies link=topic=533843.msg3903672#msg3903672 date=1328019971]

i think the vga cable could be the problem b/c i have a laptop with intel graphics and it pushs 1080p out just fine. can u use a hdmi cable with the computer?

No, the VGA standard has no limit in the amount of pixels it can push, I know full well that I’ve had a 1080p TV hooked up to my laptop just fine.

I don’t know very much about video cards. I’m using a “Intel® HD Graphics Family”.

^THIS is your problem, integrated graphics can never support very high resolution, in fact mine only supports 1024x600, my dedicated cards boosts me up to native 1600x900 though, and 1920x1080 when I need it.

I can comfortably push 1080p through VGA with Intel GMA 950, which is probably one the lowest end integrated chips out there. It wont do videos or play games at that resolution, but using the operating system and non graphic intensive applications like web browsing is not a problem.
[/quote]
I have been able to play games using a higher resolution now I have found, is it possible that my operating system can’t handle the resolution?[/quote]
GIVE US YOUR SPECS

Read full topic

item.title: Computer screen
item.dc:creator: @Andrew_Ferguson The317Guy
item.description:
@Andrew_Ferguson wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:20, topic:431163”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=533843.msg3903184#msg3903184 date=1327960379]

i think the vga cable could be the problem b/c i have a laptop with intel graphics and it pushs 1080p out just fine. can u use a hdmi cable with the computer?

No, the VGA standard has no limit in the amount of pixels it can push, I know full well that I’ve had a 1080p TV hooked up to my laptop just fine.

I don’t know very much about video cards. I’m using a “Intel® HD Graphics Family”.

^THIS is your problem, integrated graphics can never support very high resolution, in fact mine only supports 1024x600, my dedicated cards boosts me up to native 1600x900 though, and 1920x1080 when I need it.
[/quote]

I can comfortably push 1080p through VGA with Intel GMA 950, which is probably one the lowest end integrated chips out there. It wont do videos or play games at that resolution, but using the operating system and non graphic intensive applications like web browsing is not a problem.[/quote]
I have been able to play games using a higher resolution now I have found, is it possible that my operating system can’t handle the resolution?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:20, topic:431163”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=533843.msg3903184#msg3903184 date=1327960379]

i think the vga cable could be the problem b/c i have a laptop with intel graphics and it pushs 1080p out just fine. can u use a hdmi cable with the computer?

No, the VGA standard has no limit in the amount of pixels it can push, I know full well that I’ve had a 1080p TV hooked up to my laptop just fine.

I don’t know very much about video cards. I’m using a “Intel® HD Graphics Family”.

^THIS is your problem, integrated graphics can never support very high resolution, in fact mine only supports 1024x600, my dedicated cards boosts me up to native 1600x900 though, and 1920x1080 when I need it.
[/quote]

I can comfortably push 1080p through VGA with Intel GMA 950, which is probably one the lowest end integrated chips out there. It wont do videos or play games at that resolution, but using the operating system and non graphic intensive applications like web browsing is not a problem.[/quote]
Again, depends on the age and the overall spec, motherboard and cpu of the system, but looking at the specs of that it appears you can support up to 2048x1536, one of few I would’ve thought. Wouldn’t say it was a low end integrated chip

Read full topic

item.title: Computer screen
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:20, topic:431163”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=533843.msg3903184#msg3903184 date=1327960379]

i think the vga cable could be the problem b/c i have a laptop with intel graphics and it pushs 1080p out just fine. can u use a hdmi cable with the computer?

No, the VGA standard has no limit in the amount of pixels it can push, I know full well that I’ve had a 1080p TV hooked up to my laptop just fine.

I don’t know very much about video cards. I’m using a “Intel® HD Graphics Family”.

^THIS is your problem, integrated graphics can never support very high resolution, in fact mine only supports 1024x600, my dedicated cards boosts me up to native 1600x900 though, and 1920x1080 when I need it.
[/quote]

I can comfortably push 1080p through VGA with Intel GMA 950, which is probably one the lowest end integrated chips out there. It wont do videos or play games at that resolution, but using the operating system and non graphic intensive applications like web browsing is not a problem.[/quote]
you can? i wouldnt have believed that. i should try that on my acer aspire one.

Andrew Ferguson:

Well thanks for the help guys, I’m going to try with an HDMI cable tomorrow, and if it doesn’t work I can always just take it back.

do you have another device that can use a hdmi cable? it makes a ton of difference if you do.

Read full topic

item.title: Computer screen
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:14, topic:431163”][quote author=xryz link=topic=533843.msg3903156#msg3903156 date=1327959224]
i think the vga cable could be the problem b/c i have a laptop with intel graphics and it pushs 1080p out just fine. can u use a hdmi cable with the computer?
[/quote]
No, the VGA standard has no limit in the amount of pixels it can push, I know full well that I’ve had a 1080p TV hooked up to my laptop just fine.

I don’t know very much about video cards. I’m using a “Intel® HD Graphics Family”.

^THIS is your problem, integrated graphics can never support very high resolution, in fact mine only supports 1024x600, my dedicated cards boosts me up to native 1600x900 though, and 1920x1080 when I need it.[/quote]

I can comfortably push 1080p through VGA with Intel GMA 950, which is probably one the lowest end integrated chips out there. It wont do videos or play games at that resolution, but using the operating system and non graphic intensive applications like web browsing is not a problem.

Read full topic

item.title: Computer screen
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“xryz, post:17, topic:431163”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=533843.msg3903184#msg3903184 date=1327960379]

i think the vga cable could be the problem b/c i have a laptop with intel graphics and it pushs 1080p out just fine. can u use a hdmi cable with the computer?

No, the VGA standard has no limit in the amount of pixels it can push, I know full well that I’ve had a 1080p TV hooked up to my laptop just fine.

I don’t know very much about video cards. I’m using a “Intel® HD Graphics Family”.

^THIS is your problem, integrated graphics can never support very high resolution, in fact mine only supports 1024x600, my dedicated cards boosts me up to native 1600x900 though, and 1920x1080 when I need it.
[/quote]
I’m not trying to say i know better b/c ik you have more experience than i do but ik from experience. I have a laptop that is a little over a year old (http://support.gateway.com/s/notebook/2009/gateway/nv/nv54/NV54sp2.shtml < mine doesnt have nvidia it only has the intel gfx) and when i hook it up to my 1080p tv via vga it wont go to 1080p(when its hooked up through hdmi it goes to 1080p). i think the problem is the tv(on my end idk it applies to his problem) b/c the tv doesnt support those resolutions thru vga even though it can through hdmi.[/quote]
It’s possible that when you connect via VGA it’s streaming from your integrated card, but because the HDMI could be on the dedicated nVidia card, it uses that to render the desktop therefore having the extra power to push the extra pixels.

It really depends though, most recent integrated chips on the sandybridge CPU’s can support quite high resolution, but the integrated graphics on an intel celeron for example are really quite… shit.

What age is your computer OP? Or other hardware such as CPU?

Read full topic

No, the VGA standard has no limit in the amount of pixels it can push, I know full well that I’ve had a 1080p TV hooked up to my laptop just fine.

I don’t know very much about video cards. I’m using a “Intel® HD Graphics Family”.

^THIS is your problem, integrated graphics can never support very high resolution, in fact mine only supports 1024x600, my dedicated cards boosts me up to native 1600x900 though, and 1920x1080 when I need it.[/quote]
I’m not trying to say i know better b/c ik you have more experience than i do but ik from experience. I have a laptop that is a little over a year old (http://support.gateway.com/s/notebook/2009/gateway/nv/nv54/NV54sp2.shtml < mine doesnt have nvidia it only has the intel gfx) and when i hook it up to my 1080p tv via vga it wont go to 1080p(when its hooked up through hdmi it goes to 1080p). i think the problem is the tv(on my end idk it applies to his problem) b/c the tv doesnt support those resolutions thru vga even though it can through hdmi.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

There are some software that can somewhat help resolve this. I use a program called zoomtext (mostly for my vision) but anyway what it has is a feature to set your display to the lowest screen possible. I have got mine down to like 600x400 so you never know.

B2300 T4nk:

Which cable(s) are you using?

Standard computer cable, it’s built to be used as a computer too.

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:8, topic:431163”][quote author=Andrew Ferguson link=topic=533843.msg3903060#msg3903060 date=1327953116]
It’s a 1080p flat screen though so I figured it would be able to handle a little higher of a resolution.
[/quote]
Well that means it should support up to 1920x1080, it’s definitely a graphics card problem then, you using integrated?[/quote]
I don’t know very much about video cards. I’m using a “Intel® HD Graphics Family”.

item.title: Computer screen
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Just for diagnosis purposes, hook an xbox up to it, and go to the display settings and see what is listed as the max resolution there that works. If that resolution is higher than 1024x768 then it’s most likely your graphics card/integrated graphics that cannot push the pixels.

Read full topic

item.title: Computer screen
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

While the computer may be able to show a higher resolution, it’s possible that the TV can’t.

Read full topic

item.title: Computer screen
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

^ and yea, your screen probably can’t handle it. Hardware related problems I believe. My dad’s situation was a little worse, he actually got a blue screen of death on his mini when he changed his display and resolution.

Read full topic

If it can’t go more than 1024x768 then that means it can’t handle more pixels.
